trial_identification.studytitle: Effect of breakfast on children's cogntion and satiety.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Acute studies of meals high in dairy foods in children - effects on cognition and satiety

interventions.interventions: Three beverages that differ in gylcaemic load (GL) and dairy composition. Beverage 1 (High GL/No dairy)- Glucose 65g, water, flavouring Beverage 2 (Medium GL, medium dairy) - Whole milk 200ml, water, sweetener, flavouring Beverage 3 (Low GL/High dairy) - Whole milk 400ml, non-nutritive sweetener, flavouring. The participants will consume each of the three beverages over 3 consecutive days - i.e. Beverage 1 on day 1, Beverage 2 on day 2 and Beverage 3 on day 3 (randomised). Frequency of intake is once per day (consumed at 0900), for 3 days.
interventions.comparator: No control - crossover design. Each participant will have all 3 beverages (as described above) over 3 consecutive days.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Speed of Processing - Inspection Time (Burns & Nettelbeck, 2003)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline and at 1h, 2h, and 3h post beverage consumption for three consecutive days.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Simple Reaction Time - computerised task Danthiir (2005, unpublished thesis). A known stimulus (e.g. the number 1) is presented in a known location (e.g. middle of computer screen), at variable time intervals. The participant responds by pressing a specific key (e.g. the space bar). The dependent variable is the time take (msec) to respond after presentation.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline and at 1h, 2h, and 3h post beverage consumption for three consecutive days

primaryOutcome.outcome: Choice Reaction Time - computerised task Danthiir (2005, unpublished thesis). One of two known stimuli (e.g. the numbers 1 or 2) are presented in a known location (e.g. middle of computer screen). The participant is required to respond by pressing a specific key for each stimulus. The dependent variable is the time taken (msec) to respond after presentation.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline and at 1h, 2h, and 3h post beverage consumption for three consecutive days.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Speed of Processing - Digit Symbol Coding (WISC-IV). (Wechsler, 2003).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline and at 1h, 2h, and 3h post beverage consumption for three consecutive days.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Short Term Memory. Computerised version of the Rey Auditory Verbal Learning Test (RAVLT). (Rey, 1964).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline and at 1h, 2h, and 3h post beverage consumption for three consecutive days.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Working Memory - Digit Span Backwards. Computerised version of WISC-IV subtest. (Weschler, 2003).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline and at 1h, 2h, and 3h post beverage consumption for three consecutive days.
Baseline and at 1h, 2h, and 3h post beverage consumption for three consecutive days.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Blood Glucose. Using Continuous Glucose Monitoring System (CGMS). (Medtronic, 2005).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Continuously from 0800h to 1330h for three consecutive days. The beverage is consumed at 0900, so glucose will be measured for 1 hour prior to beverage consumption (baseline) and for 4.5 hours post beverage consumption.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Children aged 10-12 years. Willing to attend on four mornings in one week of the school holidays. Willing to attend fasted (from midnight of previous day). Willing to undertake Continous Glucose Monitoring. Informed child and parental consent. Parent judgement about child's ability to complete congitive testing requirements (e.g. ability to comprehend and sustain attention).
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Currently on a prescribed diet of any description. Known allergy to dairy foods or lactose intolerant. Type 1 diabetes.

trial_design.concealment: Participants will be allocated to conditions by computer program (www.randomization.com)/

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation(CSIRO) - Human Nutrition

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The aim of the study is to examine the effect of dairy consumption on satiety and certain aspects of cognition in a sample of primary school children aged 10-12 years. It is hypothesized that beverages with a lower glycaemic load and higher dairy composition will be associated with improvements in measures of cognitive function and satiety compared to beverages high in gylcaemic load and containing no dairy food.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: CSIRO Human Nutrition Human Research Ethics Committee (HREC)
